The thread began with an email from Jessa Galosmo. At 7:13 AM she wrote to Brenna, stating she was following up on the liability decision for the claim and the acknowledgement for the letter of representation that had been sent on March 27, 2024. She signed as Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm, providing her phone number (502) 357-9975 and fax number (502) 364-9363, and included a confidentiality notice indicating the transmission is privileged and confidential and should be delivered only to the named addressee(s). The notice also warned recipients that if they were not the intended recipient, they should notify the sender and delete the communication from their system, and that the material should not be copied, stored, or retained without consent.

The following portion of the thread shows a reply from Brenna Rine, dated April 1, 2024, at about 10:40 AM. In her reply, Brenna indicated, “Please see attached letters. Thank you,” and she provided her professional contact information: Liability Adjuster for Transportation Claims at 400 NW 56th Street, Lincoln, NE 68528, representing Crete Carrier Corporation, Shaffer Trucking, and Hunt Transportation Inc. Her office phone was (402) 323-4205, with fax (402) 479-8859, and her email was brine@transclaims.com.

Later that same day, at 11:28:41 AM, the thread was forwarded to Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address, with the subject “Fwd: 2024346878.” The forwarded message retained the prior content: it was from Jessa Galosmo, and it included the header information showing the original recipient as the Filevine project email address and the date of the forward. The body of the forwarded message echoed Brenna’s prior note, “Please see attached letters,” and again carried Brenna’s signature block and the attached-letter reference.

On March 29, 2024, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to ULH Customer Service with the subject Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request and, in the thread, to the Filevine project email address for Ala Cristobal (AlmaCristobalMVAZ4471403@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The message from Jessa included the line “Hi, Please see attached file,” and carried Jessa’s firm signature block, including the phone and fax numbers, with the closing “All the best, Jessa Galosmo” and the firm’s contact information.

The forwarded chain shows a response from ULH Customer Service dated April 2, 2024, around 2:44 PM, addressed to Jessa Galosmo. The reply stated: “We have received your request, please allow 30-45 for processing before calling for an update or sending another request as that may delay the first request. Thank You.” The message was signed by Robinlynn Brown, Customer Service Specialist, Accounts Receivable Operation, and included her contact email robinlynn.brown@uoflhealth.org.

The ULH message also contained organizational background text describing UofL Health, Inc. as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation governed by an independent Board of Directors. It explained that UofL Health, Inc. is a related organization with the University of Louisville’s School of Medicine, and that, under an academic affiliation agreement, the University of Louisville serves as the academic partner with UofL Health, Inc. to maintain and enhance affiliated graduate medical education as well as its research in medicine, dentistry, nursing, and public health. A confidentiality disclaimer followed, noting that the message and any attachments are confidential and may contain information privileged or exempt from disclosure under applicable law, including Protected Health Information (PHI) under HIPAA. It advised that if you were not the intended recipient, dissemination, distribution, or copying of the message is prohibited, and to report receipt to the sender or to the UofL Health IT Service Desk at 502-588-7003.

The chain also shows the original message from Jessa Galosmo to ULH Customer Service dated Friday, March 29, 2024 at 10:57 AM, subject Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request. That message included a prominent security-alert banner warning that the message is from an outside sender and advising caution, including instructions to review links carefully and to click the “Report Phishing” button to notify the security team. The body of the March 29 email simply stated, “Hi, Please see attached file.” It was signed by Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s phone and fax numbers, followed by a second closing line of “All the best, Jessa Galosmo” and the same contact details.

Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024
Client: Alma Cristobal

ORR response: Message to requester
MetroSafe is in receipt of your request. The public records you seek are in active use, storage, or not otherwise available. As such the department needs additional time to gather the records to fill your request. Additional time is necessary because:

· The scope of the request is broad; and as such we must search multiple archives for the different types of records you’re requesting.

· The records contain a mixture of exempt and nonexempt information, as such the records must be reviewed for the required redactions and action taken to redact the information. This included listening to the entire audio file multiple times to ensure all required redactions are completed.

Pursuant to KRS 61.872(5), any non-exempt, responsive records will be available through NextRequest on or before close of business 5/13/2024.
episodes.natural_language:
Case Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 involves client Alma Cristobal. The ORR response indicates that MetroSafe has received the requester’s public-records request and that the records sought are currently in active use, in storage, or otherwise not available. Accordingly, the department needs additional time to gather the records to fulfill the request.

The delay is necessary because the scope of the request is broad and requires searching multiple archives for the different types of records requested. The records contain a mixture of exempt and nonexempt information, so they must be reviewed for redactions, and action must be taken to redact the information. This included listening to the entire audio file multiple times to ensure all required redactions are completed. Pursuant to KRS 61.872(5), any non-exempt, responsive records will be available through NextRequest on or before close of business 5/13/2024.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. Client: Alma Cristobal.

On May 23, 2024, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm forwarded to Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address a message titled “FW: Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request.” The forwarded note begins with the line: “No records from Mary and Elizabeth Hospital but with UofL hospital.”

The forwarded chain then contains a message from May 22, 2024 at about 5:48 PM in the “Itemized Bills” thread, sent to Jessa Galosmo with the subject “FW: Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request.” That message itself was a forwarding of a prior message from ULH Customer Service.

The original ULH message was sent on April 2, 2024 at 2:44 PM to Itemized Bills, with the subject “FW: Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request.” It was authored by Robinlynn Brown, a Customer Service Specialist in Accounts Receivable Operation, whose email address is robinlynn.brown@uoflhealth.org. The message includes a lengthy description of UofL Health, Inc.: it is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation governed by an independent Board of Directors, and it is a related organization to the University of Louisville’s School of Medicine (defined under 42 CFR 413.17). UofL Health, Inc., on behalf of its teaching hospitals and providers, has an academic affiliation agreement with the University of Louisville whereby the University’s Health Sciences Center serves as the academic partner to maintain and enhance graduate medical education and its related research.

The message also contains a Confidentiality Disclaimer stating that the email and attachments are confidential and may contain protected health information (PHI) under HIPAA; if you are not the intended recipient, dissemination or copying is prohibited, and recipients should notify the sender or contact the UofL Health IT Service Desk at 502-588-7003 if the message was received in error.

In the April 2, 2024 ULH message, the sender addressed to Jessa: “Hi Jessa, We do not have any accounts for the dates request where patient was seen at Mary and Elizabeth Hospital. We do show patient was at UofL Hospital. Please respond with an updated request and authorization and I will gladly send to you. Thanks! Brenda S.”

Within the same thread, before the April 2 correspondence, the chain shows a prior message from Jessa Galosmo sent on Friday, March 29, 2024 at 10:57 AM to ULH Customer Service with the subject “Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño-Bill request.” That March 29 message contains a security notice: “SECURITY ALERT! This message is from an outside sender! Please review with caution and only open links you know are safe. Please click the ‘Report Phishing’ button on your tool bar to report this message to the security team for review.” The body of Jessa’s message is brief: “Hi, Please see attached file.” It is signed with all the standard closing lines from Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm, including contact information: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.

In summary, the correspondence centers on an Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño bill request. The ULH response indicates there were no accounts for the dates when the patient was seen at Mary and Elizabeth Hospital, but records show the patient was at UofL Hospital, and an updated request with authorization was requested in order to proceed. The May 23 forwarding note explicitly records the statement that there were no Mary and Elizabeth Hospital records, only records at UofL Hospital. The attachments mentioned in the March 29 email are not shown in this note, but the message confirms that Jessa had sent an attachment and followed up with ULH accordingly.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. Client: Alma Cristobal. This note documents the communications surrounding a certified medical records and billing request for Alma Cristobal, born 06/27/1990, in connection with the Alma Cristobal MVA case.

On July 23, 2024, at 2:37 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent Dorothy Brown at Aptiva Health a message requesting certified medical records and billing for the above-referenced client. She noted that if Dorothy had questions, she should contact them directly to discuss them in further detail. The message included the sender’s signature with Sarena’s title and the firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

Dorothy Brown replied on July 29, 2024, at 4:39 PM with good afternoon and stated that she had attached the medical and billing records for Alma Cristobal. The message was accompanied by an image attachment labeled image001.png and was signed by Dorothy.

On July 30, 2024, at approximately 9:28 AM, Sarena responded, “Received, thank you so much Dorothy! :)” and again included her standard signature with the firm’s contact information, noting the new email address.

Shortly thereafter, at about 9:31 AM, Sarena sent another message indicating that, upon review, the certification page appeared to be missing and asking Dorothy to forward it. The message included the same signature block.

That afternoon, at 6:41 PM UTC, Dorothy Brown replied, “Sorry about that. Here is that certification page,” and she attached the certification page as an image attachment (image001.png). The message was again signed by Dorothy.

Throughout the exchange, the correspondence circulated among The Whaley Law Firm and Aptiva Health. Dorothy Brown’s email address is shown as dbrown@aptivahealth.com, and Sarena Tuttle’s contact details reflect the firm’s Louisville address, with the new email address included in her signature: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

In the matter captioned Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024, the client is Alma Cristobal. The case is styled Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corpora, with docket numbers 108134 and 2024346878. The matter involves Alma Cristobal as the plaintiff and Crete Carrier Corporation as the defendant, and the file includes a Filevine project email address for Ala Cristobal.

On August 6, 2024, Aletha N. Thomas, a partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, wrote to Bryce Koon, of The Whaley Law Firm, stating that she had been retained to represent Crete Carrier Corporation and Roy Hamilton regarding an accident that occurred on February 15, 2024. She believed Bryce represented Alma Cristobal. Aletha attached a copy of the Answer she had filed on Crete’s behalf. She noted that Roy Hamilton had not yet been served, but she would file an Answer on his behalf after service. She also asked Bryce to send a copy of the discovery requests accompanying his Complaint to her in Word format. Aletha provided her firm’s contact details, including address (462 South Fourth Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202), telephone, and fax numbers, and she listed that the firm has offices in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin. She included a confidentiality disclaimer stating that the email may contain confidential information and that, if received by someone not the intended recipient, review or distribution is prohibited, with instructions to inform her firm and destroy the transmittal. The message was followed by Kopka Pinkus Dolin’s standard signature and note about the firm’s relocation. This message was scanned for threats by Mimecast.

Between these communications, Bryce Koon subsequently sent an email to Aletha with the subject line referencing the same case, stating, “Please see attached. If there is anything else you need from me in this regard, please let me know.” In the header, the email identified Bryce as the sender and Aletha as the recipient, with cc’d addressees including agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Nichole M. Priddy at nmpriddy@kopkalaw.com, and Ala Cristobal’s Filevine project address (Ala Cristobal - Filevine Project Email Address).

On Friday, August 23, 2024, in a follow-up, Aletha N. Thomas wrote to Bryce, asking him to send the discovery requests to Crete in Word format. In the same message, Aletha noted Kopka Pinkus Dolin’s relocation: effective August 28, the firm would be moving to 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 1670, Louisville, KY 40202; her email, telephone number, and fax number would remain the same. The firm’s offices remained in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin. Aletha’s signature reiterated the confidentiality notice, and the message included the firm’s standard closing. The email chain also carried Kopka Pinkus Dolin’s confidentiality notice and the customary disclaimer about confidential content.

The entire exchange concludes with the standard attorney-client confidentiality notices and the Mimecast-scan certification indicating the messages were scanned for email threats.

This note covers communications in the Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 case, involving client Alma Cristobal and related counsel and entities. The matter is titled Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 with the client listed as Alma Cristobal, and it concerns a February 15, 2024 accident involving Crete Carrier Corpora (as reflected in the subject lines of the exchanged emails).

On August 6, 2024, Aletha N. Thomas, a Partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, wrote to Bryce Koon and Nichole M. Priddy. In that email, she stated she had been retained to represent Crete Carrier Corporation and Roy Hamilton regarding the February 15, 2024 accident. She believed Bryce Koon represented Alma Cristobal. Aletha attached a copy of the Answer she had just filed on behalf of Crete Carrier Corporation. She noted that Mr. Hamilton had not yet been served, but she would file an Answer on his behalf once he was served. She also indicated that she understood discovery requests had been propounded with the Complaint and asked Bryce to send her a copy of those discovery requests in Word format. The email included Aletha’s contact information and firm details: Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, 462 South Fourth Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202, with telephone numbers and office locations in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin. A confidentiality notice accompanied the message, stating that the email may contain confidential information and, if received by an unintended recipient, review, copying, or distribution is prohibited; recipients were asked to destroy the original transmittal and notify the sender. It also provided a standard firm disclaimer and contact links and noted that the firm’s office was moving.

The same August 6 email contained a firm signature block for Aletha N. Thomas and reiterated the relocation information. It stated that the Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC offices would be relocating effective August 28 to 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 1670, Louisville, KY 40202, while Aletha’s email address, telephone number, and fax number would remain the same. It also included the firm’s disclaimers, office locations, and links to their website, vCard, map, and email.

On August 23, 2024 at approximately 8:24 PM (note: the timestamp is recorded as 8:24?PM in the forwarding), Aletha followed up with Bryce Koon regarding the same matter. She wrote to Bryce, with Nichole M. Priddy CC’d, asking him to send her the discovery requests to Crete in Word format. The body of the message read: “Hi, Bryce, Just following up on this. Could you please send me the discovery requests to Crete in Word format? Thank you!” The email again carried Aletha’s Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC signature block, including their Louisville address and relocation notice, and included the confidentiality notice.

This August 23 email was part of a chain that was later forwarded. On August 24, 2024 at 09:16:19 AM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm forwarded the chain to Sarena Tuttle. The forwarded content began with the same headers and included the August 23, 2024 message from Aletha N. Thomas, as described above. The forward shows the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022, and the “Forwarded message” header and related copy of Aletha’s email.

In sum, the exchanged communications document Crete Carrier Corporation’s representation by Aletha N. Thomas in connection with the February 15, 2024 accident, the status of service on Roy Hamilton, the existence of discovery requests associated with the Complaint, and Aletha’s request to receive those discovery requests in Word format. They also establish that Bryce Koon may represent Alma Cristobal, that Aletha had filed an Answer on Crete’s behalf, and that Hamilton’s responsive pleading would follow upon service. The emails also provide Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC’s contact details, the firm’s relocation to a new Louisville address, and standard confidentiality notices, along with a forwarded chain that includes Whaley Law Firm’s involvement.

Case: Alma Cristobal, assigned to the Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 file, concerns a new appointment request for the client Alma Cristobal related to her February 15, 2024 motor vehicle accident (MVA). The communications are between Aptiva Health and The Whaley Law Firm, with multiple recipients and copies.

On August 26, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, reported that Mrs. Cristobal had stopped by the office and described ongoing issues with her left shoulder and upper extremity. She stated there is continuous pain in the left shoulder that radiates down her side and sometimes into her left arm all the way to her first digit. She also noted puffiness in the clavicle region, although there was no discoloration at that time. Sarena requested that someone reach out to Mrs. Cristobal to schedule a follow-up appointment and to consider MRI imaging.

Later that same day, August 26, 2024 at 3:54 PM, April Mullins, an A/R Specialist / Lien Negotiator and Attorney Liaison at Aptiva Health, replied to Sarena with a question: Is this still under Mrs. Cristobal’s 2/15/24 MVA? In her signature she identified herself and provided her contact information and company details, including that she had included Aptiva Health’s call center team to confirm appointment information once scheduling occurs.

On August 27, 2024 at 9:43 AM, Sarena responded to April with, “Good morning April, Yes, it is,” confirming that the case remains tied to the 2/15/24 MVA.

That same day, August 27, 2024 at 1:51 PM, April replied, “We can work on getting her back in. I have included our call center team who can confirm appointment information once she’s scheduled.”

The chain of communication also notes that the initial exchange carried the subject Alma Cristobal – New Appointment Request, and that Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm were CC’d, along with the Aptiva Health CallCenter. The parties and contact details referenced include Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm (713 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) with direct line 502-357-9971, office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address). For Aptiva Health, April Mullins’s information lists Office 502-909-0772, Cell 502-428-1346, amullins@aptivahealth.com, aptivahealth.com, and the address 12300 Plantside Dr, Louisville, KY 40299, with the call center email callcenter@aptivahealth.com.

Case: Alma Cristobal, MVA-2-15-2024. On August 27, 2024, Sarena made the initial client contact with Alma Cristobal regarding her status after the motor vehicle accident. The client appreciated the update and was told that Aptiva has confirmed they will reach out to schedule an appointment. Alma explained that the clavicle area is swollen, an observation seen yesterday, and Sarena agreed that there is definite puffiness, which was communicated to Aptiva. A request for an MRI was made.

Sarena advised Alma to describe the sensations she is feeling to her provider to help determine whether they are nerve-related (tingling, numbness) or muscle-related (burning, pulling). Alma expressed understanding and appreciated the assistance with her appointment.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma Cristobal (Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024) involves a new appointment request for the client Alma Cristobal. Over the dates of August 26–27, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm and Aptiva Health exchanged a series of messages to address follow-up care after a motor vehicle accident and to arrange an appointment, including consideration of MRI imaging if indicated.

On Monday, August 26, 2024, at 3:40 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, informed April Mullins that Mrs. Cristobal had visited the office that day and reported ongoing issues with her left shoulder and upper extremity. She described continuous pain in the left shoulder that radiates down the side and sometimes into the left arm all the way to the first digit, with puffiness in the clavicle region though there was no discoloration at this time. Sarena requested that someone follow up with the patient to schedule an appointment and consider possible MRI imaging.

At 3:54 PM later that day, April Mullins replied, asking whether this is still under the 2/15/24 motor vehicle accident. She noted that follow-up would be arranged and included her contact information along with Aptiva Health’s call center details, as well as the office address: Aptiva Health, 12300 Plantside Dr, Louisville, KY 40299. Her message carried her signature block with office and cell numbers (Office: 502-909-0772; Cell: 502-428-1346), email amullins@aptivahealth.com, and the website aptivahealth.com. The email also contained standard confidentiality language and images indicated by embedded cid attachments.

Earlier the same day, at 9:43 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied to April: “Good morning April, Yes, it is,” confirming that the matter remained under the 2/15/24 MVA.

In another exchange at 9:51 AM on Tuesday, August 27, 2024, April Mullins wrote back: “We can work on getting her back in. I have included our call center team who can confirm appointment information once she’s scheduled.” This message also included April’s standard contact information and confidentiality notice.

At 10:11 AM on August 27, 2024, Sarena Tuttle responded: “Awesome. Thank you so much,” indicating appreciation for the plan to schedule the appointment.

Finally, at 3:42 PM on Tuesday, August 27, 2024, Lisa Acton sent an email to Sarena Tuttle and April Mullins, with Greg Whaley, Bryce Koon, and CallCenter CC’d. The subject was in reference to Alma Cristobal’s new appointment request, and the body stated, “Good morning, this patient has been scheduled for an appointment today with our provider. Thank you and have a good day!” This message confirms that an appointment was scheduled for the patient, with the call center to confirm appointment details.

In summary, the timeline shows the patient presenting with persistent left shoulder and upper-extremity pain after a February 15, 2024 motor vehicle accident, concerns about possible MRI imaging, and a coordinated effort between The Whaley Law Firm and Aptiva Health to schedule an appointment for August 27, 2024, after confirming the case remains under the MVA, and arranging call-center support for appointment confirmation.

Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), sent an email with the subject “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal” to ULH HIM ROI, Patient Services, and ULH Customer Service. Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024
Client: Alma Cristobal

Re: Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal DOB 06/27/1990

In July 2024, The Whaley Law Firm began a correspondence with Aptiva Health regarding certified medical records and billing for their client, Alma Cristobal (DOB 06/27/1990). The initial request was sent by Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: new email address). The subject was “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal DOB 06/27/1990.” The message stated: “Please find attached our office's request for certified medical records and billing on the above referenced client. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.”

Aptiva Health responded on July 29, 2024, with Dorothy Brown replying: “Good afternoon, Please see the attached medical and billing records for Alma Cristobal.” Dorothy’s contact includes her Aptiva Health email, dbrown@aptivahealth.com.

Earlier, on July 23, 2024 at 2:37 PM, Sarena Tuttle had written: “Good afternoon Dorothy, Please find attached our office's request for certified medical records and billing on the above referenced client. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” Sarena’s signature block also noted her new email address.

The following exchange occurred on July 30, 2024: At 9:31 AM, Sarena wrote: “Upon review, it appears we are missing the certification page. Can you please forward?” Dorothy replied at 2:41 PM: “Sorry about that. Here is that certification page.” Sarena followed at 2:57 PM with: “Received, thank you so much Dorothy! :)”

In a later development, on September 26, 2024, at 14:31:08 -0400, Sarena M. Tuttle sent a follow-up to Dorothy Brown requesting an update to the certified medical records and billing package. She explained that Alma had returned to Aptiva in August for follow-up visits and asked that those new records and billing be added to the request and certification. The message was signed with Sarena’s role and contact details, reiterating the new email address.

Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. The client is Alma Cristobal, born 06/27/1990. On July 23, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm, through Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, sent a request for certified medical records and billing for Alma Cristobal to ULP Radiology Associates. The message was addressed to Sholanda Wilson at University of Louisville Physicians and was copied to Patient Services and ULH ROI. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details appeared in the signature: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (D) 502-357-9971; office line (O) 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.” The email's subject was “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal DOB 06/27/1990.” In the body, Sarena stated that on July 23, 2024, the firm requested certified medical records and billing on their client from ULP Radiology Associates, and she noted that on August 1, 2024, ULP had provided a response. However, after review, the billing for DOS 02/15/2024 remains missing, and she requested the request be reworked to cover any and all dates of service from 02/15/2023 through 07/23/2024, as listed on the request.

The email thread includes a later reply from Gannon Middleton, ROI Tech in Health Information Management at UofL Health, who wrote “Received” on July 23, 2024, at approximately 3:22 PM. Earlier in the thread, on the same day (Tuesday, July 23, 2024), Sarena Tuttle sent a message to Patient Services and ULH HIM ROI with the subject “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal DOB 06/27/1990.” That message carried a security alert banner indicating it was from an outside sender and instructing caution, including guidance to review links carefully and to report phishing if necessary. In the body of that message, Sarena stated, “Good afternoon, Please find attached our office’s request for certified medical records and billing on the above referenced client. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, with the same contact information as above, and again noted the new email address.

In summary, the case involves a formal request for Alma Cristobal’s certified medical records and billing, originally sent July 23, 2024, with a follow-up on August 1, 2024 noting a missing DOS 02/15/2024 billing and requesting a rework to encompass all dates of service from 02/15/2023 through 07/23/2024, and it documents the email exchanges and acknowledgments that followed, including the initial attachment of the request and the acknowledgment from UofL Health’s ROI team.

episodes.natural_language:
Case Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 concerns client Alma Cristobal, born June 27, 1990. The matter involves a request for certified medical records and billing, coordinated between Dorothy Brown of Aptiva Health and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with the file maintained under Alma Cristobal.

On July 23, 2024, at 2:37 PM, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS), sent Dorothy Brown at Aptiva Health a request for certified medical records and billing for Alma Cristobal (DOB 06/27/1990). The email stated that this was the office’s request for certified medical records and billing for the referenced client and invited Dorothy to contact them if there were questions. The email included Sarena’s contact details and signature noting the new email address.

On July 29, 2024, at 4:39 PM, Dorothy Brown replied with the attached medical and billing records for Alma Cristobal, and included an image labeled cid:image001.png@01DB1105.6EE4AAF0.

On July 30, 2024, there was additional correspondence. At 9:28 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied, “Received, thank you so much Dorothy! :)” Later that day, at 9:31 AM, Sarena sent a follow-up message noting that, upon review, the certification page appeared to be missing and asking Dorothy to forward it. Dorothy responded later that day, at 2:41 PM, with the certification page included (and another image attached, cid:image001.png@01DB1105.6EE4AAF0), apologizing for the oversight. At 2:57 PM, Sarena replied, “No problem, thank you!”

Between July 30 and August 2024, the thread appears to have included ongoing coordination, but the next substantive update comes later in September.

On September 26, 2024, at 2:31 PM, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Dorothy Brown requesting an update to the original request and certification to reflect follow-up visits Alma Cristobal had conducted at Aptiva in August. She asked that the request and certification be updated with Alma’s new records and billing.

On September 27, 2024, at 21:48:18 UTC, Dorothy Brown sent the updated records and bills, along with the certification page, confirming the updated documentation. The message stated, “Good afternoon, Here are the updated records and bills along with the certification page,” and was sent to Sarena Tuttle. The message also included a note and an image attachment (cid:image001.png@01DB1105.6EE4AAF0) as part of the updated certification page.

__[External Message Added] Louisville Metro Government public records request #24-12999__
From: Louisville Metro Government Public Records [messages@nextrequest.com](mailto:messages@nextrequest.com)
To: sarena@whaleylawfirm.com 
CC: 
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2024 14:11:33 +0000

Louisville Metro Government

************************************************************************

A message was sent to you regarding record request #24-12999:

Specific to your request for body/dash camera video: I have located video responsive to your request. This record(s) is not otherwise available. Our department needs additional time to prepare the records for release. Extension for release is necessary because the requested records require additional steps before it can be made available for public release. As the requested record was created during the course of police business, it is expected to contain a mixture of exempt and non-exempt information. The exempt information is likely of a personal nature of the involved person(s) or CJIS-protected information, which is prohibited from release.

To go further into detail which is specific to the process of researching, locating and redacting body/dash camera video requests. Currently, our unit only has four members who are solely responsible for the entire department's open records requests where body/dash camera video are being requested. (As well as any audio/video which are included in case file requests). For each request we are assigned we must conduct a search by officer and date. If video is located, we must determine whether an investigation/court case related to the incident is open. We then must download each video, one at a time, and then watch and manually redact any exempted information. We do this to protect the privacy of our citizens as well for CJIS security requirements. Unfortunately, only one item/image/sound may be redacted at a time; if there are multiple exempt items, they must be redacted individually. There is no automatic process to redact exempt items. For every minute of video it is estimated it takes 7 minutes of “redaction/review”. Some requests take as little as 30 minutes to an hour to complete, while some can take over a week. And often one request doesn't equal one video. Some requests can have two, five, ten, etc.

 

For all the reasons stated above, pursuant to KRS 61.872(5), the non-exempt responsive records will be made available on or before March 7th, 2025.

 

To remain fair and unbiased to requestors, we process in the order they are received. Our unit currently has an estimated 1,000+ pending requests for video. We are working as diligently as possible given the resources and personnel allotted to our unit. If we get to your request ahead of the quoted date, it will be provided earlier.

Video may be provided faster via subpoena if applicable.

************************************************************************ 
Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at Louisville Metro Government.Technical support: See our help page
episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns Case Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 and the client Alma Cristobal. On October 15, 2024, at 14:11:33 UTC, Louisville Metro Government Public Records sent an external message regarding public records request #24-12999 to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. The request sought body and dash camera video responsive to the inquiry.

The Public Records unit states that they located video responsive to the request, and that this record is not otherwise available. They need additional time to prepare the records for release. An extension is necessary because the requested records were created during the course of police business and are expected to contain a mixture of exempt and non-exempt information. The exempt information is likely of a personal nature related to the involved person(s) or CJIS-protected information, which is prohibited from release.

The message explains the process the unit follows to research, locate, and redact body/dash camera video requests. Currently, the unit has four members who are responsible for the department’s open records requests involving body/dash camera video and any audio/video included in case file requests. For each request, staff must search by officer and date. If video is located, they must determine whether an investigation or court case related to the incident is open. They then download each video one at a time, watch it, and manually redact any exempt information to protect citizens’ privacy and to meet CJIS security requirements. There is no automatic redaction; only one item, image, or sound may be redacted at a time, so multiple exempt items must be redacted individually. For every minute of video, it is estimated to take seven minutes to redact and review. Consequently, some requests take as little as 30 minutes to an hour, while others can take over a week. A single request does not necessarily correspond to a single video, as some requests may involve two, five, ten, or more videos.

Based on these factors, and pursuant to KRS 61.872(5), the non-exempt responsive records will be made available on or before March 7, 2025. To remain fair and unbiased, the unit processes requests in the order they are received. They currently have an estimated 1,000+ pending requests for video and are working as diligently as possible given the resources and personnel allocated. If a request is completed earlier than the quoted date, it will be provided sooner. The notice also notes that video may be provided faster via subpoena if applicable.

For questions about the request, you may reply to the email or sign in to contact staff at Louisville Metro Government. Technical support is available via the help page.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. Client: Alma Cristobal. Re: 108134: 2024346878: Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corpora: Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-004728).

The matter involves communications among counsel regarding discovery and scheduling in the case Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, filed in Jefferson County (24-CI-004728). On October 7, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Aletha N. Thomas, Esq., of Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, with Nichole M. Priddy cc’d and Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address also included in the cc list (AlmaCristobalMVAZ4471403@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The subject of the message referenced the matter as 108134: 2024346878: Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corpora: Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-004728). Koon’s message stated that he was following up on discovery requests served to Defendant Crete and requested any updates. The email included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and a standard confidentiality disclaimer, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact the firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information. The message also contained a note indicating that the email had been scanned for threats by Mimecast, and included Kopka Pinkus Dolin’s confidentiality notice.

On October 9, 2024, at 3:42? PM, Aletha N. Thomas responded. She thanked Bryce for the email and his patience and advised that she was awaiting her client’s verification of the responses and would transmit them as soon as she received them. Her signature block identified her as a partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, with office locations in Louisville; her contact details, and a standard confidentiality disclaimer similar to the one included in the prior message.

On November 1, 2024, at approximately 12:08 p.m., Bryce Koon, Esq., again wrote to Aletha Thomas and others, attaching the motion. He stated that the motion was set for Monday, November 11, at 9:45 a.m. and added that if their client’s responses were received prior to that date, he would be happy to remand the motion. He closed with his contact information for The Whaley Law Firm. The message included the same standard attorney-client privilege language and confidentiality notices, and reiterated the firm’s disclaimer about privileged information and the proper handling of the email if received in error. The email chain also included Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address in the cc list: AlmaCristobalMVAZ4471403@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

Earlier in the chain, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent a separate note on November 1, 2024 at 2:02 p.m. to Bryce Koon and others. She advised that the motion hour had been moved by the clerk to November 12, 2024, due to Veterans Day on November 11. Her message included her contact details, including direct dial and office phone numbers, her new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), and The Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222). Her signature also indicated she provided the update in her capacity as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager. The email again carried standard confidentiality and privilege notices, including a reminder not to use or forward the information if received in error, and noting that it had been scanned for threats by Mimecast.

In sum, the record reflects an ongoing discovery process regarding defendant Crete in the Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation matter, with initial follow-ups on discovery in early October, a motion email in early November indicating a hearing set for November 11 at 9:45 a.m. (subject to remand if client responses were received beforehand), and a clerk-led rescheduling notice moving the hearing to November 12, 2024 due to Veterans Day. The communications involved counsel from The Whaley Law Firm and Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, included Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project contact, and contained standard confidentiality and privilege notices common to attorney communications.

Case file Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 concerns Alma Cristobal and Crete Carrier Corporation in the Jefferson County matter (case caption Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al., Jefferson 24-CI-004728). The client listed is Alma Cristobal. The note aggregates a series of email communications between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Aletha N. Thomas, Partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, with additional copies to Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address and to Nichole M. Priddy, as well as to Sarena Tuttle. The subject line tracks the docket: 108134 : 2024346878 : Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al. The dates span from early October to November 1, 2024, and there is a motion attached to the November 1 message, with a hearing set for November 11, 2024 at 9:45 a.m.

On October 7, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an email to Aletha N. Thomas following up on discovery requests served to Defendant Crete, requesting any available update. The message was cc’d to Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project address and to Nichole M. Priddy, with the subject continuing to reference the Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation matter (Jefferson 24-CI-004728). The email closed with Koon’s firm’s contact information. A confidential-attorney-client privilege disclaimer accompanied the message, noting that if the email was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information; a note also directed the recipient to the Kopka law firm website for further information, and a Mimecast-scan notice indicated the email had been checked for threats.

In response, on October 9, 2024, Aletha N. Thomas acknowledged Bryce’s email and expressed appreciation for his patience. She stated she was awaiting her client’s verification of the responses and would forward them as soon as she received them. Thomas’s signature block followed, showing her title as Partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, the Louisville, Kentucky office address (101 South Fifth Street, Suite 1670, Louisville, KY 40202), phone and fax numbers, a direct line and cell number, and a note that the firm has offices in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin. Her email signature also included a website link, a vCard, and a map link.

Earlier, on October 7, 2024, Bryce Koon’s message had included a recurring subject line for the matter and a nominal follow-up request for updates on the discovery requests served to Crete Carrier Corporation. The email contained a standard confidentiality notice and privilege disclaimer, along with a reminder that the message had been scanned for threats by Mimecast.

Finally, on November 1, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another email to counsel with the attached motion, noting that the motion is set for Monday, November 11, at 9:45 a.m. He stated that if they receive the client’s responses prior to that date, he would be happy to remand the motion. He invited any questions regarding this matter. This message carried the same confidentiality caveat and privilege language as the earlier communications, and the cc list again included Alma Cristobal’s Filevine project email address, Nichole M. Priddy, and Sarena Tuttle. The overall thread documents ongoing discovery efforts in the case and a pending motion with a hearing date set for early November.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al. (Jefferson County 24-CI-004728), assigned case Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024, the client is Alma Cristobal. The Re line establishes the docket codes 108134 and 2024346878 in the caption, with the parties identified as Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation, et al. The communications involved The Whaley Law Firm and Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, with the principal participants being Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm; W. Bryce Koon, Esq., also of The Whaley Law Firm; Aletha N. Thomas, Esq., and Nichole M. Priddy, Esq., both of Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC; and Alma Cristobal via a Filevine project email address.

On October 7, 2024, Bryce Koon, Esq., wrote to Aletha N. Thomas, Esq. to follow up on discovery requests served to Defendant Crete, noting that any update would be appreciated. The email was sent at 3:38 PM and copied to Alma Cristobal (via Filevine Project Email Address) and Nichole M. Priddy. The message included standard firm disclosures and confidentiality notices, stating that the email may contain confidential information and that the recipient should not review, copy, or distribute it if not the proper recipient, with a warning to inform the sender and destroy the transmittal if received in error. The message also bore a disclaimer about attorney-client privilege and included Mimecast’s threat-scanning notice.

Aletha N. Thomas, in an email dated October 9, 2024 at 3:42 PM, responded to Bryce. She thanked him for the email and patience and said she was awaiting her client’s verification of the responses, which she would forward as soon as she received them. Her signature identifies her as a Partner at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, with offices listed in Louisville, Kentucky, and with additional offices in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin. Her contact details and firm branding appeared in the message.

Later, on November 1, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another email regarding the case. At approximately 12:08 PM (the time is noted as “12:08?PM” in the record), he advised counsel to review the attached motion, which was set for Monday, November 11, at 9:45 AM, and stated that if they received the client’s responses prior to that date, he would be happy to remand the motion. He closed with his contact details for The Whaley Law Firm.

That same day, at 2:02 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle wrote to counsel to convey that the motion hour had been moved by the clerk to November 12, 2024, due to Veterans Day on November 11. Her note included her role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm and provided her direct lines and new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Her signature block also listed the firm’s Louisville address and phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104).

The November 1 communications carried the customary email confidentiality notices. Bryce’s message reiterated that the motion hour had been moved and referenced the attached motion and the potential for remand contingent on timely responses. The record also bears the standard firm disclaimers indicating that the messages are intended for the named recipients and may contain privileged information, with instructions to contact the sending firm if received in error, and to refrain from sharing or using the information beyond its intended recipient. The October 7 and October 9 exchanges likewise carried the firm’s confidentiality notices and Mimecast threat-scanning notices.

In summary, beginning with the October 7 discovery follow-up, through the October 9 client-verification update, and culminating in the November 1 scheduling communications, the parties discussed discovery responses and a motion in the Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corporation matter. On November 1, 2024, the motion’s original November 11, 9:45 AM time was adjusted to November 12, 2024 by the clerk owing to Veterans Day, with Bryce indicating flexibility to remand if client responses were provided beforehand.

episodes.natural_language:
In November 2024, the Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier and Roy Hamilton case moved into the deposition scheduling phase. On November 21, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Aletha N. Thomas and Nichole M. Priddy requesting dates for the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton, since the initial written discovery had been completed by both parties. She asked that Aletha or Nichole provide dates when their office and Mr. Hamilton would be available for deposition. The email included her firm’s contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address. A confidentiality disclaimer was included, stating that the email may contain confidential information and should be destroyed if received by the wrong recipient, and directing the recipient to visit www.kopkalaw.com for more information.

Earlier that same day, Nichole M. Priddy, a legal assistant at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, replied to Bryce Koon and Sarena. She explained that Aletha’s calendar was booked from now until after the first of the year and, after reviewing Aletha’s calendar, proposed the weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14 for the deposition. Nichole noted that Aletha would also want to depose Ms. Cristobal herself and asked for Ms. Cristobal’s schedule during that time frame. She also stated she would contact Mr. Hamilton to determine dates that would work for him so that the scheduling could be coordinated for all parties. Nichole signed the message as the Legal Assistant to Aletha N. Thomas, Partner, and Kristin Lomond, Senior Attorney, and provided her firm’s contact information: Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 1670, Louisville, KY 40202; phone 502-785-2818; fax 502-785-2812; direct line 502-351-0242; cell 812-572-7588; email nmpriddy@kopkalaw.com; with offices in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, and Wisconsin.

In the thread, Nichole’s message was followed by the standard confidentiality notice, and the email from Sarena again included her note about a new email address and her firm’s contact details.

The following day, November 22, 2024, Sarena replied to Nichole. She suggested the week of February 3–7 for the deposition, noting that they were pushing the scheduling out and that Ms. Cristobal would be available during that same week. She asked Nichole to let them know what date and time would work best for Nichole’s office and for Mr. Hamilton. The email again carried Sarena’s contact details and the confidentiality notice, along with the reminder that the message originated from her new email address.

Throughout the exchanges, the case information remained clear: Alma Cristobal was the client, the defendants were Crete Carrier and Roy Hamilton, and the parties were coordinating the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton, with Ms. Cristobal also to be deposed. The proposed deposition windows were the weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14, with the preference to schedule as soon as possible within those windows, and Ms. Cristobal’s availability noted for the week of February 3–7.

Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024
Client: Alma Cristobal

In the matter of Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corp. and Roy Hamilton (108134: 2024346878), deposition scheduling correspondence occurred between Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC and The Whaley Law Firm in late November 2024. The client is Alma Cristobal.

On November 21, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, wrote to Aletha N. Thomas and Nichole M. Priddy requesting dates for deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton, noting that the initial written discovery had been completed by both parties and that they were ready to move forward with scheduling. Nichole M. Priddy, a legal assistant at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC and assistant to Aletha Thomas and Kristin Lomond, replied later that day. She explained that Aletha’s calendar was booked from now until after the first of the year and, after reviewing Aletha’s calendar, proposed the weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14 as potential windows. Nichole added that Aletha would also want to depose Ms. Cristobal and asked for Cristobal’s availability during that timeframe. She stated she would contact Mr. Hamilton to determine dates that would work for him so the deposition scheduling could be coordinated for all parties.

The following day, November 22, 2024, Sarena Tuttle responded, suggesting the week of February 3–7 as a practical focus given how far out the scheduling had become. She noted that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week as well and asked Nichole and her office to indicate what dates worked best for their side and for Mr. Hamilton.

On November 26, 2024, Nichole M. Priddy informed Sarena that she had heard back from Mr. Hamilton, and he advised that February 5, 2025, would be suitable for his deposition, to be conducted via Zoom. This established a concrete date for the deposition of Roy Hamilton, with the expectation that the deposition of Alma Cristobal would also be arranged within the same scheduling window.

The correspondence indicates ongoing coordination to schedule the deposition of Roy Hamilton, with Aletha Thomas also intending to depose Alma Cristobal, within the suggested weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14, 2025, and with Mr. Hamilton’s availability confirmed for February 5, 2025, by Zoom. The exchange involved the principals and paralegals at Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC and The Whaley Law Firm, respectively, to finalize a mutually workable deposition schedule for all parties.

Thomas and Bryce Koon) to announce that the parties were ready to move forward with scheduling Mr. Hamilton’s deposition and to request dates when their offices and Mr. Hamilton would be available.

On November 22, 2024 at 9:06 AM, Sarena responded that they could look at the week of February 3–7 since they were already pushing out the schedule, and that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week. She asked Nichole to let them know what dates worked best for Kopka Pinkus Dolin and Mr. Hamilton, and she indicated they would accommodate accordingly.

Subsequently, on November 26, 2024 at 9:29 AM, Nichole informed that Mr. Hamilton had advised February 5, 2025 would be good for him, and that the deposition would be conducted via Zoom.

That same day, November 26, 2024 at 10:52 AM, Sarena replied that February 5, 2025 via Zoom was perfect. She added a logistical question about timing: she asked how much time Mrs. Thomas would need, or typically takes, and proposed two possible schedules. One option was to start at 10:00 a.m. with Ms. Cristobal and to have Mr. Hamilton begin at 1:00 p.m. to allow time for lunch; alternatively, they could proceed immediately following the Cristobal deposition. She provided her contact information and signed off with her title and firm details. The overall plan remained to conduct the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton via Zoom on February 5, 2025, with Ms. Cristobal’s deposition to occur in the surrounding time window, subject to the parties’ schedules.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corp. and Roy Hamilton (Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024) concerns scheduling depositions in the Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier and Roy Hamilton matter. The parties’ counsel, Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC, and The Whaley Law Firm coordinated a Zoom deposition schedule for Roy Hamilton, with Aletha Thomas (Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC) also intending to depose Alma Cristobal.

On November 21, 2024, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Aletha Thomas and Nichole Priddy asking for dates when their office and Mr. Hamilton would be available to depose him, noting that initial written discovery had been completed and they were ready to proceed with the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton.

That same day, Nichole Priddy, a legal assistant at Kopka Pinkus Dolin, replied that Aletha’s calendar was pretty booked from now until after the first of the year. She wrote that, upon review, they could offer the weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14, and that Aletha would also want to take the deposition of Alma Cristobal as well. Nichole asked for Cristobal’s schedule during that time frame and said she would contact Mr. Hamilton to coordinate dates for all parties.

The following day, November 22, 2024, Sarena responded that they should look at the week of February 3–7, since they were already pushing the schedule out. She noted that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week and asked Kopka Pinkus Dolin to share dates that worked for their office and for Mr. Hamilton.

On November 26, 2024, Nichole Priddy informed Sarena that Mr. Hamilton advised February 5, 2025 would be suitable for a deposition via Zoom.

That same day, November 26, 2024, Sarena replied that February 5, 2025 via Zoom was perfect, and she asked whether they should start at 10:00 a.m. with Ms. Cristobal and then have Mr. Hamilton begin at 1:00 p.m. to allow time for lunch, or whether they should conduct the depositions immediately following one another.

Nichole Priddy responded later that day, agreeing with the proposed plan. She noted she was not sure how much time Aletha would need, but she thought the arrangement suggested by Sarena sounded good. The parties’ communications thus established a Zoom deposition for February 5, 2025, with Cristobal scheduled at 10:00 a.m. and Hamilton at 1:00 p.m., while allowing for Aletha’s potential needs.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case of Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corpora, docketed as Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024, the parties moved to schedule the deposition of Roy Hamilton after the initial written discovery had been completed. On November 21, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Nichole M. Priddy of Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC (cc’ing Aletha N. Thomas and Bryce Koon) asking for dates that Mr. Hamilton and the offices could be available for deposition. The subject line of that message referenced the matter as 108134 : 2024346878 : Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corpora : Alma Cristobal v Crete Carrier & Roy Hamilton - Deposition Scheduling. In that note, Sarena wrote, “Good afternoon. It appears the initial written discovery has been completed by both parties and we are ready to move forward with scheduling the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton. Can you (or Nicole) please provide dates that your office and Mr. Hamilton are available for deposition?”

Later that same day, November 21, 2024, Nichole replied that Aletha’s calendar was quite booked from now until after the first of the year and proposed the weeks of February 3–7 and February 10–14 as potential windows. Nichole also noted that Aletha would want to take the deposition of Ms. Cristobal as well and asked to be informed of Cristobal’s availability within that timeframe; she said she would contact Mr. Hamilton to coordinate dates for all parties. The message was signed with Nichole’s contact information and standard confidentiality notice.

On November 22, 2024 at 9:06 a.m., Sarena responded, suggesting that they look at the week of February 3–7 since they were already pushing things out and that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week as well. She asked Nichole to let them know what would work best for Kopka Pinkus Dolin and Mr. Hamilton.

On November 26, 2024, at 9:29 a.m., Nichole informed Sarena that she had heard back from Mr. Hamilton and that February 5, 2025 would be good for him, with the deposition to be held via Zoom.

Later that morning, at 10:53 a.m., Sarena responded that February 5, 2025 via Zoom was perfect and asked for guidance on timing. She proposed starting at 10:00 a.m. with Ms. Cristobal and beginning Mr. Hamilton’s deposition at 1:00 p.m. to allow time for lunch, or alternatively proceeding immediately after Ms. Cristobal’s deposition. She signed off with her title and contact details, noting her new Whaley Law Firm email address.

At 1:18 p.m. on the same day, Nichole replied that the suggested plan sounded good and that she was not sure how much time Aletha would need, but she agreed with the proposed timing. Her message also carried Kopka Pinkus Dolin’s standard confidentiality notice and her contact information.

Finally, at 2:14 p.m., Sarena sent a closing note confirming that she would obtain a deposition notice for Mr. Hamilton and send it over shortly, with her usual signature block and new email address.

In summary, after confirming that initial discovery had been completed, the team settled on scheduling the deposition of Roy Hamilton for February 5, 2025, via Zoom, with Ms. Cristobal’s deposition included in the same window. They discussed starting times—10:00 a.m. for Cristobal and 1:00 p.m. for Hamilton to allow for lunch, or proceeding consecutively—depending on the time Aletha Thomas would need. The coordinated dates were set within the week of February 3–7, 2025, within the broader February 3–14, 2025 timeframe, with Mr. Hamilton’s availability confirmed for February 5.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. Client: Alma Cristobal. The matter is Alma Cristobal v Crete Carrier Corpora and Roy Hamilton, specifically the deposition scheduling for Mr. Roy Hamilton.

A Notice to Take the Deposition of Mr. Hamilton was filed, with the subject line 108134 : 2024346878 : Cristobal, Alma v. Crete Carrier Corpora : Alma Cristobal v Crete Carrier & Roy Hamilton - Deposition Scheduling. The notice was submitted by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and was filed moments ago via CourtNet Envelope 9361828.

The scheduling dialogue began on November 21, 2024, when Sarena Tuttle sent a message to Nichole M. Priddy (and copied Aletha N. Thomas) asking for dates when their offices and Mr. Hamilton would be available for deposition, noting that initial written discovery had been completed and they were ready to move forward with the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton. She asked whether her office or Nichole could provide dates.

Later that same day, Nichole M. Priddy responded that Aletha’s calendar was pretty booked through the end of the year, and, after reviewing Aletha’s schedule, proposed the week of February 3–7 and the week of February 10–14 for scheduling. Nichole also indicated that Aletha would also want to depose Ms. Cristobal and asked to learn Cristobal’s availability in that time frame. Nichole also stated she would contact Mr. Hamilton to coordinate dates for all parties.

On November 22, 2024, Sarena replied that they should look at the week of February 3–7 since they were already pushing out, and that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week as well; she asked them to let her know what worked best for Nichole’s office and Mr. Hamilton.

On November 26, 2024, Nichole reported that Mr. Hamilton had advised February 5, 2025 would be good for him, and that the deposition would be via Zoom.

Later that morning, November 26, 2024, Sarena responded that February 5, 2025 via Zoom was perfect and proposed scheduling with Ms. Cristobal’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. and Mr. Hamilton’s at 1:00 p.m. to allow for lunch, or alternatively continuing immediately after. She noted she was unsure how much time Aletha would need but suggested the times could accommodate that consideration.

That afternoon, November 26, 2024, Nichole wrote back agreeing with the proposal, stating she was not certain how much time Aletha would need, but that the plan as proposed sounded good.

Shortly after, at 2:14 p.m., Sarena indicated she would prepare and send the notice for Mr. Hamilton shortly.

At 2:14 p.m. (approximately), Sarena again confirmed she would prepare a notice for Mr. Hamilton and send it to Nichole shortly, with the notice subsequently being filed via CourtNet Envelope 9361828.

In short, the parties have coordinated to schedule the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton for February 5, 2025, to be conducted by Zoom, with a tentative plan to depose Alma Cristobal that same day beginning at 10:00 a.m., followed by Mr. Hamilton at 1:00 p.m., allowing for a lunch break if needed. The planning also anticipated including the deposition of Ms. Cristobal as part of the same scheduling window, reflecting Aletha Thomas’s calendar considerations and the overall coordination among The Whaley Law Firm and Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC.

Case: Alma Cristobal v. Crete Carrier Corpora and Roy Hamilton (Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024) involved a sequence of email communications in late November 2024 about scheduling the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton and Ms. Alma Cristobal. The matter was identified as 108134 with the caption 2024346878.

On November 21, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, sent an email to Nichole M. Priddy of Kopka Pinkus Dolin PC (along with Aletha N. Thomas and Bryce Koon on copy) noting that initial written discovery had been completed by both parties and requesting available dates for the deposition of Mr. Roy Hamilton. 

Later that day, Nichole replied that Aletha’s calendar was booked for the near term and proposed two blocks of time for depositions: the week of February 3–7, 2025 or the week of February 10–14, 2025, with the deposition of Ms. Cristobal to be included as well. She added that she would contact Mr. Hamilton to determine which dates would work and provided a link to her vCard for easy contact.

On November 22, 2024, Sarena responded that the week of February 3–7, 2025 was preferable given the current scheduling, and that Ms. Cristobal would be available that week. She asked Nichole to confirm what would work best for Kopka Pinkus Dolin and for Mr. Hamilton.

By November 26, 2024, Nichole reported that Mr. Hamilton had advised February 5, 2025 would be suitable for a deposition via Zoom. Sarena replied that February 5, 2025 via Zoom was perfect and raised a question about timing: whether to start at 10:00 a.m. with Ms. Cristobal and have Mr. Hamilton begin at 1:00 p.m. to allow for lunch, or to schedule the depositions back-to-back immediately after one another. Nichole responded that the proposed times sounded good, though she could not say in advance how much time Aletha would need.

Sarena then stated that she would prepare a deposition notice for Mr. Hamilton and send it shortly. She later informed Nichole that the notice for Mr. Hamilton had been filed via CourtNet under envelope 9361828.

Separately, Nichole had noted in a November 26, 2024 email that she would get the Notice for Ms. Cristobal over to the opposing office shortly, indicating that notices for both deponents were being pursued in connection with the case.

In summary, the parties coordinated scheduling for depositions in February 2025, with Mr. Hamilton set for February 5, 2025 (via Zoom) and Ms. Cristobal available that same week. The proposed morning and afternoon slots were discussed (Ms. Cristobal around 10:00 a.m. and Mr. Hamilton around 1:00 p.m., to allow lunch), and notices for the depositions were prepared and filed (Mr. Hamilton’s notice filed via CourtNet as envelope 9361828; Ms. Cristobal’s notice to be sent separately).

episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the case Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024, involving client Alma Cristobal, with the matter titled Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal. The Whaley Law Firm represents the client, and the communications are with Starlight (also referred to as Starlite) Chiropractic. The December 11, 2024 email was sent by Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to Gail at Starlight Chiropractic, with two Starlight addresses included (lgsweasy@gmail.com and starlitechiro@gmail.com), and with CCs to Aaron Whaley (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) and Muhammad Alif (stimulus110@yahoo.com). The message was dated Wednesday, December 11, 2024, at 13:44:57 -0500.

In this December 11 communication, Sarena stated that they still had not received the Certification page for the attached records and bills that had been discussed on October 7, 2024. She explained that if a claim is in litigation, they cannot file the records or bills with the courts without a completed, signed certification page. She added that if the proper certification is not received, the treatment and/or bills cannot be considered for payment, and she urged Gail to expedite the required certification as soon as possible. The message included The Whaley Law Firm’s standard signature block, noting the new email address and providing direct and office phone numbers, along with the firm’s mailing address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222.

The chain also shows prior correspondence. On October 7, 2024, at approximately 11:46 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote, “Please find the CRR w/Certification Page Attached,” followed by the same signature block and contact information, including the note about the new email address. Before that, a forwarded message from July 23, 2024, at 2:21 PM, indicated that Sarena had sent an email to Starlite Chiropractic (and StarliteChiro@gmail.com) with the subject Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Alma Cristobal. In that July message, she stated: “Good afternoon Gail, Please find attached our office's request for certified medical records and billing on the above referenced client. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” The signature block following that message again listed Sarena M. Tuttle’s role, the firm’s address, direct and office phone numbers, the email contact, and the note to use the new email address.

Taken together, the record shows a sequence of communications from The Whaley Law Firm to Starlight/Starlite Chiropractic regarding certified medical records and billing for Alma Cristobal, culminating in a December 11, 2024 email stressing that the critical Certification page has not been received since the October 7, 2024 discussion, and outlining the consequences for filing and payment if the certification is not provided promptly.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024 concerns Alma Cristobal, born 06/27/1990, in a motor vehicle accident matter. The note set documents an ongoing Certified Medical Records and Billing request, with a detailed email chain between The Whaley Law Firm and Aptiva Health.

On January 21, 2025, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Dorothy Brown at Aptiva Health, copying Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm. In that message, she stated that, after reviewing the attached records for Alma Cristobal, the first few visits appear to be missing: specifically the dates 04/02/2024, 04/08/2024, and 05/16/2024. She requested that those dates of service be added and that the package be sent with a corrected certification page. The message included Sarena’s contact details, noting a new email address (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) and listing her direct and office lines, as well as The Whaley Law Firm’s mailing address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. It also reiterated that Dorothy Brown’s communication should be sent from the Aptiva Health address and that Bryce Koon should be cc’d; the subject line again referenced Certified Medical Records & Billing Request for Alma Cristobal, DOB 06/27/1990.

The historical thread begins with a July 23, 2024 email in which Sarena requested certified medical records and billing for Alma Cristobal (DOB 06/27/1990). On July 29, 2024, Dorothy Brown replied that she had attached the updated records and bills, along with the certification page. Shortly thereafter, there was back-and-forth about the certification page: on July 30, 2024, Dorothy wrote, “Sorry about that. Here is that certification page.” In the same exchange, Sarena indicated that, upon review, it appeared the certification page was still missing and asked Dorothy to forward it; Dorothy subsequently responded with a confirmation that the certification page had been sent, and Sarena acknowledged receipt. The dated sequence shows multiple confirmations and acknowledgments around the certification page and the accompanying records.

In an ongoing process later in 2024, on September 26, 2024, Sarena explained that Alma had returned to Aptiva in August for follow-up visits and asked Dorothy to update the request and certification with those new records and billing. Dorothy responded on September 27, 2024 by providing updated records and bills, along with the certification page. On September 30, 2024, Sarena acknowledged receipt of those updated materials.

This sequence reflects a sustained effort to compile Alma Cristobal’s certified medical records and related billing, including updates to capture post-August follow-up visits and the necessary certification pages, with communications spanning from July 2024 through September 2024, and a final clarification and reminder on January 21, 2025 about missing early visits (04/02/2024, 04/08/2024, and 05/16/2024) requiring inclusion in the certified package.

On February 4, 2025 at 9:36:23 a.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from his Louisville office to counsel Aletha N. Thomas, copying Alma Cristobal at her Filevine project email address. The message carried the subject line Re: Cristobal v. Hamilton & Crete Carrier (Jefferson 24-CI-004728). In the body, Koon stated that he had not yet received the client’s responses to the supplemental discovery requests, and he warned that if the responses were not provided that day, tomorrow’s depositions would need to be rescheduled. The email closed with Koon’s signature block, listing The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, a telephone number, a fax number, and a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer indicating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and that, if received in error, the recipient should contact the firm and not use or forward the information.

This thread follows earlier communications. On January 30, 2025, at about 1:34 p.m., Koon wrote to counsel with a brief follow-up: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on this. Any update appreciated.” The message again included Koon’s contact information and the same privilege disclaimer.

Prior to that, on December 27, 2024 at 11:12 a.m., Koon sent the initial communication attaching the supplemental discovery request and the associated notice, noting that a Word copy was included for convenience. The requests sought any video footage of the collision in the client’s possession, and Koon asked that, if he and/or the client were not in possession of any footage of the collision, they should advise. This email also contained the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer and Koon’s signature block with the firm’s contact details.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024
Client: Alma Cristobal

Recvd ORR Resp w/Body & Dash Cam Footage - Not very helpful - Def Hamilton admits to hitting Client but states she attempted to cut him off - Client vehicle swung across in front him - No Damage to Truck - PR states it was Daylight - Video shows it was almost pitch black out - Googled Scene Location - Saved Videos to Investigation Folder
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 15, 2024, with Alma Cristobal regarding a motor vehicle accident identified as Alma-Cristobal-MVA-2-15-2024. 

Recvd ORR Resp w/Body & Dash Cam Footage - Not very helpful. The defendant, Hamilton, admits to hitting the client but states she attempted to cut him off; the client’s vehicle swung across in front of Hamilton. There was no damage to the truck. Per report, it was daylight, but video shows it was almost pitch black outside. The scene location was Googled, and the videos have been saved to the Investigation folder.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

about.relevance: admitted to hitting the client; involved party
